Award.AwardTitle: Biochemical and structural studies of gamma-secretase

Division.LongName: Div Of Molecular and Cellular Bioscience

Award.AbstractNarration:
Intellectual Merit. Biological membranes surround all living cells, confine their internal organelles, and participate in an astounding variety of essential cellular functions, including extracellular signaling, electrolyte balance and energy conversion. These membranes are structurally and chemically heterogeneous environments composed of numerous types of lipids arranged as a continuous bilayer, in which membrane proteins are either embedded or surface-associated. The goal of this project is to understand the effect of the lipid bilayer on the structure and function of the membrane protein gamma-secretase. This protease is of great importance as it is responsible for activating numerous signaling molecules involved in the regulation of neuronal function, and its substrate specificity is thought to vary with the bilayer composition. Using novel assays the research will study the effect of physical and chemical parameters of the bilayer on secretase activity. To visualize the structure of the enzyme in a membrane it will be crystallized in lipid bilayers and analyzed using electron microscopy. This project constitutes a paradigm shift in membrane protein research as it moves away from commonly used artificial detergent systems to the study of membrane proteins in their natural lipid bilayer environment.

Broader impacts. By training scientists in membrane protein research and in the principles and applications of modern structural biology, this project will provide a platform for educating the next generation of scientists at the interface of biophysics, biochemistry and biology. The PI will continue to teach electron microscopy in a course available to students from all New York City institutions. Additionally, facilitating and encouraging minority participation in the sciences through teaching, mentoring and career counseling is a key goal of this project. This project will recruit students from various backgrounds at different career stages, through existing programs such as Post Baccalaureate Research Education Program (PREP), the Summer Undergraduate Research Program (SURP), and the precollege and collegiate programs of the Center for Excellence in Youth Education (CEYE). Emphasis will be placed on raising the scientific literacy of the public by ongoing outreach activities and by hosting one local high school student every year. This student will be chosen through an ongoing collaboration with the science faculty at Great Neck South HS.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Project outcomes

By degrading transmembrane protein substrates and liberating cellular signals, intramembrane proteases regulate key processes in eukaryotic and prokaryotic biology. Conventional water-soluble proteases cleave within unstructured regions of their substrates and are unable to cleave alpha-helices. The goal of this project was to address the question of how the membrane environment modulates the activity of intramembrane proteases, and how these enzymes manage to cleave transmembrane protein sequences that are in alpha-helical conformation. To address these questions we developed a new method based on Raman spectroscopy that is capable of measuring the conformation of the substrate in a membrane-mimic environment before and after interaction with an intramembrane protease. Details of this method have been published allowing its implementation by other laboratories. Using this method we discovered that the binding of the substrate to an intramembrane protease results in a conformational change that facilitates local unwinding of the transmembrane alpha-helix that facilitates its degradation. We also discovered that intramembrane proteases select their degradable substrates based on their intrinsic flexibility and propensity to be unwound. This is a new concept in protease biology that appears to be unique for intramembrane proteases and distinguishes them from their water-soluble counterparts. Thus, the results from this NSF funded project have profound implications to understand the molecular basis of intramembrane protease action and their role as control-switches regulating a large number of key cellular processes.

 

From a broader impact perspective, this NSF-funded project has provided a framework for the training of PhD students and postdocs, and for the exposure of high-school students to science. As part of the outreach efforts, high school students from the New York City area carried out summer research in my laboratory. All of them participated in the Intel Science Talent Search, later renamed Regeneron Science Talent Search, one of the nation?s most prestigious pre-college science competitions. One of them obtained an award in the 2017 competition. Two PhD students graduated and moved onto positions in academia and in industry and two postdocs obtained positions in industry. From an education perspective the project allowed me to teach graduate courses in enzymology and structural biology. In addition, I served as co-director of the graduate program at my institution with a wide range of responsibilities, including student admissions, chairing of PhD committees, and designing the curriculum. Through my role as co-director of the graduate program I had an impact in increasing the enrollment of under-represented minority graduate students and the training of the next generation of scientists at the interface of biophysics, biochemistry and biology.
